message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mass is located in the right adnexa, which is the area near the uterus and ovaries. The size of the mass is significant and suggests the need for surgical removal. The ureter runs along the pelvic sidewall adjacent to the ovary, so it must be diligently protected during the surgery to avoid injury. Injury to the cardinal ligament of the uterus could result in uterine prolapse in the future, but this ligament is not in close proximity to the ovary. The external iliac artery is located higher and more lateral and would not be in jeopardy during surgery. The ovarian ligament is not a major structure at risk during the removal of an ovarian mass.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location and size of the mass suggest that the ureter must be diligently protected during the surgery to prevent injury. The other structures listed are not in immediate proximity to the ovary.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the right ovarian mass suggests that the ureter must be diligently protected during surgery to prevent injury or damage. The cardinal ligament of the uterus is not in close proximity to the ovary. The external iliac artery and ovarian ligament are also not in close proximity to the ovary.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A 9 cm ovarian mass requires surgical removal, but care must be taken to protect the ureter, which runs in close proximity to the ovary. The cardinal ligament of the uterus, ovarian ligament, and external iliac artery are not in close proximity to the ovary and therefore do not require special protection during surgery.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The size and location of the mass suggest that the ureter must be carefully protected during surgery to avoid damage. The cardinal ligament of the uterus and ovarian ligament are not in close proximity to the site of the mass, and the external iliac artery is not in the immediate vicinity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A 9 cm right ovarian mass suggests an ovarian cyst or tumor. During surgery, the ureter must be carefully identified and protected to prevent injury or damage. The other options do not directly involve the ovaries or adnexa, and therefore would not need to be specifically protected during this surgery.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the mass (in the right adnexa) suggests that the ureter should be diligently protected during surgery as it runs posterior to the ovarian vessels and may be compressed or damaged by the mass or during surgery. The cardinal ligament of the uterus attaches the cervix to the side wall of the pelvis, while the external iliac artery is outside of the pelvic cavity. The ovarian ligament attaches the ovary to the uterus and is less relevant to the removal of an ovarian mass.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The size and location of the ovarian mass suggest the need for surgical removal, and the proximity to the ureter means that it must be diligently protected to avoid injury during the procedure. The other options are not directly related to the removal of an ovarian mass.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A 9 cm ovarian mass is a large mass and has the potential to compress the ureters. Therefore, during surgery, it is important to diligently protect the ureters to prevent damage and subsequent complications such as urinary tract infection or kidney damage. Protecting the cardinal ligament of the uterus, external iliac artery, and ovarian ligament may also be important during surgery, but they are not the primary concern for a large ovarian mass.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the ovarian mass suggests that the ureter must be diligently protected during surgery to prevent injury or damage. The cardinal ligament of the uterus, external iliac artery, and ovarian ligament are not in close proximity to the ovarian mass and are not at high risk for injury during surgery.
